The two major Kurdish factions, the KDP (Barazani) and the PUK (Talibani), have nominated a joint list of 165 candidates

ldc_scope.charseq: The two major Kurdish factions, the KDP (Barazani) and the PUK (Talibani), have nominated a joint list of 165 candidates with token positions given to less known Kurdish parties at the end of the list

extent.charseq: A candidate would need (total number of voters/275) votes to get

ldc_scope.charseq: A candidate would need (total number of voters/275) votes to get a seat in the assembly

For example, if 10 million people vote, divide 10,000,000 by 275 and you get 36,363 votes required for a candidate to be on the assembly (actually it's 36363.6 votes but I'm not quite sure how they are going to deal with fractional numbers

extent.charseq: the top 25 members on the list get

ldc_scope.charseq: If that particular list has 200 candidates, only the top 25 members on the list get the seats

extent.charseq: the top 25 members on the list

ldc_scope.charseq: Therefore it's easy to conclude that the higher a candidate's name is on the list, the more likely they would get a seat

extent.charseq: elections for a permanent government should be held no later than December 15, 2005

ldc_scope.charseq: Following the approval of the constitution, elections for a permanent government should be held no later than December 15, 2005 [Article 61(D

extent.charseq: elections for a new National Assembly held no later than December 15, 2005

ldc_scope.charseq: Note that if the National Assembly fails to draft a permanent constitution by August 15, 2005 or if the draft is rejected in the referendum, the National Assembly should be dissolved and elections for a new National Assembly held no later than December 15, 2005 [Article 61(E
